bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Harald Bode (1909-1987) was an electrical engineer who made several innovative developments in the design of electronic music instruments. His early work led to the creation of his Warbo Formant-Orgel in 1937, and his Melodium in 1938. He emigrated from Germany to Brattleboro, Vermont in 1954 to work as director of research and development for the Estey Organ Company. In 1960 he moved to North Tonawanda, New York, where he designed a new model of an electronic piano for Wurlitzer and founded his own company, Bode Sound Company. He later worked as chief engineer for Bell Aerospace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Collection contains folders of documents pertaining to Bode Sound Company products, including the Barberpole Phaser, Frequency shifters, and Vocoder. It also contains a folder of material from R. A. Moog, Inc. about its Vocoder. Moog developed one of the first solid-state musical vocoders for the electronic music studio established by Lejaren Hiller at the University at Buffalo in 1968.
